definition: lit. as rare as phoenix feathers and unicorn horns (idiom)/fig. few and far between

hair/feather/down/wool/mildew/mold/coarse or semifinished/young/raw/careless/unthinking/nervous/scared/(of currency) to devalue or depreciate/classifier for Chinese fractional monetary unit ( = 角[jiao3] , = one-tenth of a yuan or 10 fen 分[fen1])
angle/corner/horn/horn-shaped/unit of money equal to 0.1 yuan, or 10 cents (a dime)/CL:個|个[ge4]
role (theater)/to compete/ancient three legged wine vessel/third note of pentatonic scale

sentences.english: Hispanic senators have been few and far between, as have Hispanic governors.
sentences.chinese: 西語裔的參議員和州長更是鳳毛麟角。

sentences.english: It's just very few people in the world can do it well.
sentences.chinese: 世界上能把這些工作做好的人可以說是鳳毛麟角。

sentences.english: "Rare" means precious and rare people who used an analogy with holiness.
sentences.chinese: 鳳毛麟角“指珍貴而不可多得用來比喻有聖德的人。

sentences.english: And it is still relatively rare for journalists to win access.
sentences.chinese: 能進入朝鮮的外國記者仍然只是鳳毛麟角。

sentences.english: Persons who can write such poems now are already very rare.
sentences.chinese: 能寫出如此詩句的人，現在已經是鳳毛麟角了。

sentences.english: Unfortunately, opportunities to listen to a great speaker are few and far between.
sentences.chinese: 可惜，能夠聆聽到優秀的演講的機會鳳毛麟角。

definition: can be counted on one's fingers (idiom)/very few
lit. only one branch of the tree is thriving (idiom)/fig. to be in a league of one's own/outstanding
to run neck and neck/to keep pace with/to keep abreast of/on a par with one another
unprecedented and never to be duplicated/the first and the last/unmatched/unique
to emerge as a new force to be reckoned with (idiom)
